conclusion: At t = 0 s the sky-diver’s speed is 0 m s⁻¹.
At t = 10 s the speed has risen to a little above 20 m s⁻¹ (≈ 22 m s⁻¹).
The curve between 0 s and 10 s rises steeply at first and then flattens.
The average speed during this interval is a bit more than one-half of the final speed.
Treat the 0–10 s part of the curve as roughly triangular for a first estimate.
Average speed ≈ (0 + 22 m s⁻¹) / 2 ≈ 11 m s⁻¹.
The true area under the curve—and hence the true distance—will be slightly larger than this triangle estimate.
Even the conservative triangular estimate already gives 110 m, so the real distance fallen in the first 10 s is definitely greater than 100 m.
